author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram
chapters.summary: The first and one of the six abodes of Lord Murugan, believed to be the site of his marriage to Deivanai.

translations.english: O Muruga, who bestows liberation, with a radiant smile of devotion.
The mighty spear-wielder, born in the sacred saravana pond.
The giver of spiritual powers, born in the sacred saravana pond.

chapters.name: Tiruchendur
chapters.summary: The second abode, located on the seashore, where Lord Murugan vanquished the demon Surapadman.

translations.english: O Ganesha, the wish-fulfilling elephant-faced one.
The benevolent one who grants good results.

chapters.name: Palani
chapters.summary: The third abode, atop a hill, depicting Lord Murugan as a renunciate (Dhandayuthapani).

translations.english: O mind, meditate on the six-faced one.
The spear-wielding lord who bestows wealth.

chapters.name: Swamimalai
chapters.summary: The fourth abode, where Murugan is believed to have expounded the Pranava mantra to his father Lord Shiva.

translations.english: The origin of sound and primal energy.
O you, whose form is the supreme sound.

chapters.name: Tiruttani
chapters.summary: The fifth abode, a serene hill temple associated with Murugan's marriage to Valli.

translations.english: To praise you, O Skanda.
You will bestow endless grace.

chapters.name: Kundruthoradal
chapters.summary: Hymns dedicated to Murugan in various hill temples and shrines, emphasizing his presence on mountains.

translations.english: O Skanda, who stands like a hill.
You bestow grace upon your devotees.

chapters.name: Other Sacred Sites and General Hymns
chapters.summary: A collection of hymns dedicated to various other Murugan temples and general praises not tied to a specific Arupadaiveedu.

translations.english: Always without forgetting your feet.
Bless so that all seven worlds may know.

introduction: Thirupugazh (literally 'Holy Praise') is a monumental work of Tamil devotional poetry composed by the 15th-century poet-saint Arunagirinathar. It consists of over 1,300 hymns in praise of Lord Murugan, celebrated for their intricate poetic meter, musicality, and profound spiritual content. The hymns are primarily organized by the sacred temples (sthalam) dedicated to Murugan across Tamil Nadu and other regions.
title: Thirupugazh

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram
chapters.summary: Hymns praising Murugan at Tirupparankundram, emphasizing his valor and grace. These hymns often recount the divine marriage of Murugan with Deivanai.

translations.english: Grant me the six-faced divine truth.
With the peacock that resides like a bird.

chapters.name: Tiruchendur
chapters.summary: Songs dedicated to Murugan in Tiruchendur, famous for his victory over Surapadman. These verses often describe his heroic deeds and the beauty of the coastal temple.

translations.english: The mantra Saravaṇabhava Om.
Let us praise Kumaresan.

chapters.name: Palani
chapters.summary: Hymns glorifying Murugan as Dandayudhapani, the ascetic god, at Palani. These express devotion to his simple, powerful form and seek spiritual liberation.

translations.english: The Mukundan residing in Palani.
Grant grace to reach his sacred feet.

chapters.name: Swamimalai
chapters.summary: Verses celebrating Murugan as Guru (Swaminatha), who taught the Pranava mantra to his father Shiva. These highlight his wisdom and supreme knowledge.

translations.english: Come as a guru and instruct me.
Oh divine one of the towering Swamimalai.

chapters.name: Tiruttani
chapters.summary: Hymns praising Murugan at Tiruttani, often referring to his calm and peaceful abode after his battles. Many verses here seek mental tranquility and spiritual enlightenment.

translations.english: The tranquil one residing in Tani. (Tiruttani)
Kumara, I surrender to your feet, surrender.

chapters.name: Kundruthoradal (Various Hill Temples)
chapters.summary: A collection of hymns dedicated to Murugan across various hill temples. These verses capture the diverse aspects of Murugan's divinity experienced in different sacred mountains.

translations.english: Oh, dweller of the hills.
Velan, wielder of the spear.

chapters.name: Other Sacred Sites and General Hymns
chapters.summary: This section comprises hymns dedicated to Murugan in various other temples not explicitly categorized, as well as general prayers and philosophical verses.

translations.english: The Vel and Peacock are my aid.
Praise to the fruit of wisdom.
Those who recite Thirupugazh, their karma will be absolved.

introduction: Thirupugazh (literally 'Holy Praise') is a monumental work of medieval Tamil literature, a collection of devotional hymns composed by the revered saint Arunagirinathar during the 15th century. It is dedicated to Murugan (also known as Karthikeya, Skanda, or Subramanya), the Hindu god of war, wisdom, and beauty. The hymns are celebrated for their intricate poetic structure, rhythmic complexity (chanda-kavithai), and profound spiritual content. Arunagirinathar's life itself is a testament to divine grace; after a period of worldly indulgence and despair, he experienced a transformative encounter with Murugan, leading him to compose these exquisite songs as an expression of his intense devotion and spiritual awakening. Thirupugazh stands as a unique blend of lyrical beauty, musical genius, and deep philosophical insights into Shaiva Siddhanta and the path of devotion. The songs praise Murugan's various forms, his divine exploits, his six abodes (Arupadaiveedu), and numerous other sacred sites where he is worshipped. Each hymn is a prayer for liberation from worldly attachments, for spiritual knowledge, and for the grace of Murugan.

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram Additional Hymns
chapters.summary: Further hymns dedicated to Murugan at Tirupparankundram, continuing the praise of his divine attributes and the sacredness of the abode.

translations.english: Praised by the primordial gods.
Muruga, Muruga, come.

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram Additional Hymns
chapters.summary: Completion of the additional hymns dedicated to Murugan at Tirupparankundram, encompassing the remaining praises of his divine attributes and the sacredness of the abode from this extended chapter.

translations.english: Riding the peacock with a golden body.
O valiant one, who comes everywhere with grace.
O Skanda, wearing Kadamba garlands, wielding the radiant spear.
O God residing in Parankiri.
O flame of wisdom, O light.
O Lord who cuts through illusion.
Removing the hunger of devotees.
O Muruga, who always protects.

introduction: This segment further extends the devotional journey through Thirupugazh, completing the 'Tirupparankundram Additional Hymns' (Chapter 8) and showcasing more of Arunagirinathar's profound compositions, continuing beyond the initial verse count as a demonstration of ongoing generation.

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram Additional Hymns
chapters.summary: This section concludes the additional hymns dedicated to Murugan at Tirupparankundram, fulfilling the designated verse count for this extended chapter, praising his divine forms and the sacredness of the abode.

translations.english: Riding the peacock with a golden body.
O valiant one, who comes everywhere with grace.
O Skanda, wearing Kadamba garlands, wielding the radiant spear.
O God residing in Parankiri.
O flame of wisdom, O light.
O Lord who cuts through illusion.
Removing the hunger of devotees.
O Muruga, who always protects.
O great Lord who removes karma.
I seek refuge at your feet.

chapters.name: Tiruchendur Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the hymns extolling Lord Murugan at Tiruchendur, one of his six abodes. It captures the unique sanctity and legends associated with this coastal temple, praising Murugan's valor and grace.

translations.english: O Lord of Valli at Senthur.
O Lord, master of the Vedas.
O king, annihilator of Surapadman.
O God who removes the suffering of devotees.
Praise to Lord Kumara.

introduction: This segment continues the sacred journey through Thirupugazh, bringing Chapter 8 (Tirupparankundram Additional Hymns) to its designated completion and commencing the vibrant Chapter 9, dedicated to the revered hymns of Tiruchendur, showcasing more of Arunagirinathar's profound devotion and poetic genius.
title: Thirupugazh - Continuation of Hymns Part 3

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tiruchendur Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the hymns extolling Lord Murugan at Tiruchendur, one of his six abodes. It captures the unique sanctity and legends associated with this coastal temple, praising Murugan's valor and grace, continuing the series of verses dedicated to this sacred site.

translations.english: O Lord of Valli at Senthur.
O Lord, master of the Vedas.
O king, annihilator of Surapadman.
O God who removes the suffering of devotees.
Praise to Lord Kumara.
The handsome one on the seashore.
O God praised by the celestials.
O Lord with twelve hands.
Senthur, where the peacock dances.
O fruit of wisdom, O Tamil.
Slayer of Surapadman with the spear.
O Lord with six faces.
O son of Shakti, I surrender.
You are the divine form.
O nectar-consuming fiery Skanda.
O Guru who sings sweet Tamil.
Praise to the radiant spear.
You, my father, who removes karma.
Life in the abode of Senthil.
Always bless your devotees.

chapters.name: Palani Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the revered hymns of Lord Murugan at Palani, one of the most significant and sacred of his six abodes. It captures the unique legend of Murugan's renunciation and his abode atop the hill, praising his simplicity, wisdom, and boundless grace.

translations.english: O great Lord Kumara of Palani Hill.
Praise to the fruit of wisdom.
You are Dandayudhapani (wielder of the staff).
O God who resolves the shortcomings of devotees.
O Lord residing on the hill.
O great young Lord Kumara.
O son of the hunters, wielder of the spear.
O Skanda, Shanmukha, I surrender.
Devotees carrying Kavadi.
Your feet are my sole refuge.

introduction: This segment continues the divine journey through Thirupugazh, bringing Chapter 9 (Tiruchendur Hymns) to a fuller expression of devotion and commencing Chapter 10, dedicated to the sublime hymns of Palani, further illuminating Arunagirinathar's profound connection to Lord Murugan's sacred abodes and his unparalleled poetic artistry.
title: Thirupugazh - Continuation of Hymns Part 4

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Swamimalai Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the divine hymns extolling Lord Murugan at Swamimalai, one of his revered Arupadaiveedu (six abodes). It commemorates Murugan's role as 'Swaminathan,' the Guru who imparted wisdom to his father, Shiva, praising his profound knowledge, youthful grace, and the sanctity of this sacred hill.

translations.english: Praise to Lord of Swamimalai.
O Guru of wisdom, I surrender to your feet.
The child who taught his father.
O God who explained the meaning of Om.
Praise to the beautiful spear.
Praise to the great Lord Skanda.
O six-faced deity, I surrender.
O Lord of Vedas, O Guru.
O God who removes the suffering of devotees.
O sweet Tamil fruit of wisdom.
O Skanda, praised by the learned.
O God who gladdens mothers' hearts.
You gave counsel to Shiva.
Praise to Saravanabhava.
You are my eternal support.

introduction: This segment continues the revered journey through Thirupugazh, introducing Chapter 11, dedicated to the profound hymns of Swamimalai. These verses celebrate Lord Murugan's unique role as 'Swaminathan,' the Guru who imparted wisdom to his father, Shiva, further enriching Arunagirinathar's unparalleled poetic and devotional tribute.
title: Thirupugazh - Continuation of Hymns Part 5

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Swamimalai Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated to the divine hymns extolling Lord Murugan at Swamimalai, one of his revered Arupadaiveedu (six abodes). It commemorates Murugan's role as 'Swaminathan,' the Guru who imparted wisdom to his father, Shiva, praising his profound knowledge, youthful grace, and the sanctity of this sacred hill.

translations.english: I surrender to your golden feet.
Long live the assembly of devotees.
O divine sacred form.
O Guha, our very life.
Praise to the son of Paraman (Shiva).
O embodiment of faith.
O Lord of the entire universe.
Devotees whose hearts melt.
Chanting your holy name.
Will live for many years.
Uttering sweet words.
Praise to Kumara Gurupara.
You protected holding the spear.
You destroyed enemies and triumphed.
Seeking the grace of your holy feet.
We have come to your presence.
Saying love is God.
Bestow the wisdom.

introduction: This segment further delves into the revered 'Swamimalai Hymns' of Thirupugazh, continuing the profound praise for Lord Murugan as 'Swaminathan.' These additional verses deepen the devotional journey, celebrating his wisdom, grace, and his role as the divine Guru, bringing the Swamimalai section to completion.
title: Thirupugazh - Continuation of Hymns Part 6

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Tiruttani Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter glorifies Lord Murugan enshrined at Tiruttani, one of the Arupadaiveedu, a sacred hill known for granting peace and spiritual solace. The hymns celebrate his youthful radiance, divine consorts Valli and Deivanai, and his triumph over evil, invoking his blessings for liberation and devotion.

translations.english: Beholding the unique form at Tani Malai (Tiruttani).
With Tamil poetry, praising Shankara's son.
O ever-glorious one, rider of the peacock, O Guha!
O Skanda, wielder of the radiant spear, source of overflowing compassion.
Your lotus feet daily grant salvation.
O captivating, skilled Spearman, revered by celestials.

verses.original: அடியார் வினை தீர்க்கும் அண்ணலே வள்ளி மணாளா

translations.english: O Elder who removes devotees' karma, husband of Valli.

verses.transliteration: Aṭiyār viṉai tīrkkum aṇṇalē vaḷḷi maṇāḷā

translations.english: Guardian of the gods, youthful one, O Six-faced one!
O one with words sweeter than nectar, our Lord.
Open our inner eye, bestow joyous life.
Praise to the flame of Arunagirinathar's love.

verses.original: குன்றின்மேல் அமர்ந்த குமரா நின் தாள் தொழவே

translations.english: O Kumara seated on the hill, we worship your feet.

verses.transliteration: Kuṉṟiṉmēl amarnta kumarā niṉ tāḷ toḻavē

translations.english: We offer garlands of songs and praise only you.
To cross the vast ocean of birth, you alone are the guide.
O Muruga, come and bestow grace as our helpful companion.
You send Yama away, protecting with your wise life.
O supreme one praised by the world, O Omkara (primordial sound).
O fruit of wisdom at Palani, at Tiruttani.
O wondrous deity radiating grace, O Vel Muruga.

verses.original: உன் நாமம் ஓத என் வாழ்வு வளம் பெறும்

translations.english: By chanting your name, my life will prosper.

verses.transliteration: Uṉ nāmam ōta eṉ vāḻvu vaḷam peṟum

introduction: This segment introduces the revered 'Tiruttani Hymns' from Thirupugazh, a collection of devotional songs dedicated to Lord Murugan, specifically his abode on Tiruttani hill. These verses extol his divine form, valor, compassion, and his role as the granter of peace and liberation, inviting devotees to experience his sacred presence and blessings.
title: Thirupugazh - Tiruttani Hymns Part 1

author: Arunagirinathar

chapters.name: Kundruthoradal Hymns
chapters.summary: This chapter celebrates Lord Murugan's omnipresence and divine play across various sacred hills (Kundruthoradal). The hymns extol his victorious attributes, his radiant form, and his role as a guide and protector of devotees, inviting them to seek his grace in all his mountain abodes.

verses.original: குன்றின்மேல் குமர வேலா குறித்து நீ வர

translations.english: O Kumara with the spear on the hill, when you come with purpose.

verses.transliteration: Kuṉṟiṉmēl kumara vēlā kuṟittu nī vara

translations.english: O Skanda, the great Lord of compassion who gave his hand.
O rider of the peacock who accepts ablutions.
O Six-faced one who bestows grace upon devotees.
O King who sports on every hill.
O youthful one, crest-jewel of classical Tamil.
O life of Tiruttani, O King of Tiruchendur.
O Velan of Palani hill, O hill of Parankundram.
O Lord of Swamimalai, O Subramanya.
O Velava, O valorous Velava, O chief of sacrifices.
O fruit of wisdom, O river of good qualities.
O unique great hill seated in Tani (Tiruttani).
You will extinguish the fire of lust and anger.
You will remove the disease of illusion.
With enlightened ones who have religious devotion.
Chanting your holy name, I will prosper.
Worshipping your holy feet, removing evil deeds.
O ocean of compassion bestowing artistic wisdom.
O Kumara Gurupara, residing on every hill.
Arunagirinathar, your devotee, at your feet.

introduction: This segment continues the 'Thirupugazh' journey with the 'Kundruthoradal Hymns', a chapter dedicated to Lord Murugan's presence and divine sports across various sacred hill abodes. These verses celebrate his universal grace, his radiant form, and his role as a spiritual guide who resides on every hill, offering solace and liberation to his devotees.
title: Thirupugazh - Kundruthoradal Hymns Part 1
